quoteFirst: August 20.—Started for Ladak again, nominally at some desperately early hour of the morning, but in reality at about
quoteLast: , the sun not shining upon our position until late, in consequence of our proximity to the mountains. Mr. Rajoo being still indisposed, and, in his own belief, dying, we mounted him upon a hill horse, where he looked like a fly on a dromedary.
title: Diary of a Pedestrian in Cashmere and Thibet
author: Knight, W. H. (William Henry)

quoteFirst: All at once her voice was interrupted by the prolonged roar of the factory's whistle, blowing as though it would never stop. It was
quoteLast: . In an instant the faint purring of the machinery dwindled and ceased, leaving an abrupt silence in the air. A moment later the army of operatives began to pour out of the main entrance; men and girls and young boys, all in a great hurry, the men settling their coat collars as they ran down the steps.
title: Vandover and the Brute
author: Norris, Frank, 1870-1902

quoteLast: ; camp has been broken and we are ready to march. The officers have returned from reporting to the major for orders and I fall in the company and give the following orders:

quoteFirst: They had made an excellent fire, and had set the kettle on it at about
quoteLast: . So that by eight the fire had been out for some time, the water had all boiled away, and the bottom was burned out of the kettle. Also they had not thought of washing the crockery before they set the table.

author: Nesbit, E. (Edith), 1858-1924

quoteFirst: At no work that he had ever written did Sir Richard labour so sedulously as at The Scented Garden. Although in feeble health and sadly emaciated, he rose daily at
quoteLast: , and slaved at it almost incessantly till dusk, begrudging himself the hour or two required for meals and exercise. The only luxury he allowed himself while upon his laborious task was "a sip of whiskey," but so engrossed was he with his work that he forgot even that. It was no uncommon remark for Dr.
title: The Life of Sir Richard Burton
author: Wright, Thomas, 1859-1936

quoteFirst: She turned over the leaves of the latter with feverish haste. Yes, there was a train which left at 2:30 and got to London at
quoteLast: ; it was a slow one--the express which started at 3:30, did not get in until nearly six. That might be too late--both might be too late, but she must try.
title: The Reason Why
author: Glyn, Elinor, 1864-1943

quoteFirst: After their work, which in port sometimes keeps them up till the morning hours, these strange creatures, untroubled by thought, stretch themselves on the wooden hatchway and sleep. There I found them at
quoteLast: in the morning, all covered with the one large sheet of canvas and never a nose poking out. Air! Perhaps they got some through a little hole in the great sheet.
title: The Pacific Triangle
author: Greenbie, Sydney, 1889-1960

quoteFirst: He knows all about it, --"Diligence, half-past four breakfast, Oh, yaas!" While I have been at the diligence-office, my companions have secured room and gone to them; and I ask the waiter to show m to my room. First, however, I tell him that we three two ladies and myself, who came together, are going in the diligence at
quoteLast: , and want to be called and have breakfast. Did he comprehend?

quoteFirst: Mrs. Jack will leave Braemar at about three o'clock and drive down to Ballater to catch the
quoteLast: train. She asks me to say that she hopes you will pardon her for the trouble she is giving you, and to impress on you that in case you would rather not come, or should anything occur to prevent you, she will quite understand a telegram with the single word 'regret.

quoteFirst: Molly had had a hint or two from her two visitors that they considered she would be making rather a slave of herself, but she had no such intention; she did not think it harder work to be in the kitchen than at the sewing-machine. At
quoteLast: she went to see if the table was neatly laid, and made a few changes, calling Marta’s attention to them; then went into the kitchen, and found the parsley and onion not nearly fine enough; these she chopped over, and by that time the potatoes and Lima beans were done.

quoteLast: . He decided to go at once to the hotel. And he went. Miss Van Tuyn was at home. He went up in the lift and was shown into her sitting-room.

quoteLast: in the afternoon, when the man whom he was beginning to look upon as a friend said sharply:

quoteFirst: In May there were route marches twice a week, the brigade going off at
quoteLast: and returning about 7.30 a.m., all in the cool of the morning or such bearable temperature as there was in the 24 hours' daily round in that month. quoteFirst: The head coachman's wife who was up with a sick child heard you get off and watched your flight over the bay in this direction.  She didn't see you fall.  But when you didn't return she became frightened and alarmed the household--woke us all at
quoteLast: .  Think of it!"  She yawned and dropped wearily on the step of the porch.  And then, as Markham went indoors in search of chairs, in a lower tone to Hermia, "With a person you have professed to detest you seem to be getting on famously, my dear.
title: Madcap

quoteLast: , we reached Capel Bay, where the passengers for Rockhampton disembarked. All the places down this coast appear to be inaccessible to large steamers.
